description: From Middle English fourthe, an alteration (due to four) of ferthe, from Old English fēorþa, fēowerþa, from Proto-West Germanic *feurþō, from Proto-Germanic *fedurþô, equivalent to four +‎ -th.

entries.meaning: The ordinal form of the number four.
(in the singular) The person or thing in the fourth position.
(chiefly US) A quarter, one of four equal parts of a whole.
(in the singular) The fourth gear of an engine.
(music) A musical interval which spans four degrees of the diatonic scale, for example C to F (C D E F).

verbs.description: fourth (third-person singular simple present fourths, present participle fourthing, simple past and past participle fourthed)

entries.meaning: (informal) To agree with a proposition or statement after it has already been thirded.
